items.title: A Year in Pasadena, Los Angeles County
items.summary: A Year in Pasadena, Los Angeles County, 2025 "the ashes will cool and however it all settles, let us make…
items.content_html:
A Year in Pasadena, Los Angeles County, 2025

"the ashes will cool and however it all settles, let us make sure that material and immaterial, presential and virtual, expressions of solidarity multiply and last," Denise Ferreira da Silva reflecting on 2020.

How to encapsulate 2025 in Los Angeles from Pasadena and Altadena horizons? First there was fire and then came ice. But that is too simple a story. The peoples' responses and acts of communal care in the face of these potent phase transitions are the highlights of the year.

items.title: Cited/Sighted Series
items.summary: Public Comfort, 2024 "Heteronormativity functions as a form of public comfort by allowing bodies to extend into spaces that have…
items.content_html:
"Heteronormativity functions as a form of public comfort by allowing bodies to extend into spaces that have already taken their shape....Heteronormativity also becomes a form of comforting: one feels better by the warmth of being faced by a world one has already taken in. One does not notice this as a world when one has been shaped by that world, and even acquired its shape. Norms may not only have a way of disappearing from view, but may also be that which we do not consciously feel" from The Cultural Politics of Emotion by Sara Ahmed

 

 

"They, like us, are alive in hydrogen, in oxygen; in carbon, in phosphorus, and iron; in sodium and chlorine" from In the Wake by Christina Sharpe

 

"But if we understand human life as a process, where process does not necessarily equal progress, even adversaries that rob us of our strength or other faculties must be seen as crucial components of this process. It is not a matter of good or bad, positive or negative; it simply is. The process is what human life is made of, and there is no point in struggling against it" from The Call of Character: Living a Life Worth Living by Mari Ruti  

 

"I shall return to my native land. Those disbelieving in the promise and refusing to make the pledge have no choice but to avow the loss that inagurates one’s existence. It is to be bound to other promises.  It is to lose your mother, always" from Lose Your Mother: A Journey Along the Atlantic Slave Route by Saidiya Hartman

items.title: 2024 in Review through Song Lyrics as Title Cards
items.summary: "Poppies" by La Luz “All this year, I thought I'd disappear / Under the weight of troubles stacking end to…
items.content_html:
"Poppies" by La Luz

“All this year, I thought I'd disappear / Under the weight of troubles stacking end to end / One or two, the first ones to break through / And now across the field, the poppies comе again”

 

"Wind Machine" by Diane Birch

“November is coming on / And the nights are getting longer / Summer always deceives / Little promises like the orange leaves”

 

"Cartagena" by Reyna Tropical

“Que me cargue la corriente / Que me acaricie el ambiente” 

 

"b i g f e e l i n g s" by WILLOW

“Even with such big feelings / I have such big feelings”

 

"La Presa" by Nathy Peluso

“Prefiero ser maleante que pendeja / Y para eso hay que tener valor”

items.title: ​An ode to the feature and "Humble Mumble" on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the release of Stankonia
items.summary: Humble Mumble 1 Humble Mumble 2 Humble Mumble 3 Humble Mumble 4 "Humble Mumble" quadtych, 2025 Originally written November 2025…
items.content_html:
"Humble Mumble" quadtych, 2025

 

Originally written November 2025

In the universe of recorded popular music, songs with features, also referred to as collaborations, are the coming together of at least two musical acts for the recording of a track for an EP, full album, soundtrack, or single. Typically, one of the musical acts serves a principal role and the recording will be a part of their project while the additional acts take a secondary role as featured guests. Collaborations unseated the duet's prominence particulary in the U.S. where the latter's connotations to romance and femininity are interpreted as artistically limiting or threatening (not to all and to prove my points listen to Beyoncé and Miley Cyrus' "II MOST WANTED").

Like duets, features are cross-promotional opportunities—outreach marketing in commercial terms. Features' immediate appeal is audience growth as a vehicle towards larger profits. A more layered appreciation of features would mention too that as financially attuned recording practices these collaborations serve other creative aspirations as introductions, experiments, favors, reinventions as well as chances to impress (fans, artists, industry folk), express affinity (with the co-performer, a genre, a region), differentiate oneself (from past persona, allegiances, actions), rebel (from expectations), and expand upon an idea (think of remixes). And let's take a sentence to give Mariah Carey credit for all her contributions to the art of collaboration.

Outkast's "Humble Mumble," featuring Erykah Badu, is a proxy for Stankonia. Nestled in the second half of the album, the track, as a collaboration and like the rest of Stankonia, is an experimental endeavor. It is an effort to redefine Outkast and the sounds of (hip-hop in) the South. Quirky and free-spirited, the track leads with a synthesized "Latin" rhythm that to me seems to be a source of what becomes the hi-hat sound now definitive of trap. Then, about a third of the way into the track, and after Big Boi's verse, the beat changes with André 3000's verse. A funk-driven beat takes over, and Big Boi is not heard again.

"Humble Mumble" foreshadows the dissolution of the duo. The track's two-in-oneness is the musical model for the recording of the Speakerboxxx/The Love Below, a two-disc album on which Big Boi leans into Southern hip-hop in Speakerboxxx and André 3000 takes a more Prince/P-Funk-inspired musical turn in The Love Below. Erykah's feature on Stankonia also prefigures André 3000's collaborations with and reliance on women—Kelis, Norah Jones, Rosario Dawson, Qasha Aman, and Toni Hunter—in the The Love Below to establish his solo persona and offset any social doubts musical experimentations might suggest.

On Stankonia, Erykah Badu's featured verse in "Humble Mumble" might be the most radically unpretentious thing about the track as well as her musical repertoire to date. She offers an elemental meditation on life. Hers is a verse that is basic in its planetary singularity. And with that mix of simplicity and candor, Erykah achieves the nonconformity she so often reaches for musically. In "Humble Mumble," she sums up her musical pursuits, wails and all, and condenses the phases of existence as could only be done through a feature.

Erykah Badu's verse on "Humble Mumble":
"I'm wild, just like a rock, a stone, a tree
And I'm free, just like the wind the breeze that blows
And I flow, just like a brook, a stream, the rain
And I fly, just like a bird up in the sky
And I'll surely die, just like a flower plucked
And dragged away and thrown away
And then one day, it turns to clay
It blows away, it finds a ray, it finds its way
And there it lays, until the rain and sun
Then I breathe, just like the wind the breeze that blows
And I grow, just like a baby breastfeeding
And it's beautiful, that's life and that's life (Ahhhh)
And that's life and that's life"

items.title: Longing for "La Ingrata"
items.summary: Originally written in 2017 “La Ingrata” is a track off of Mexican rock band Café Tacuba’s 1994 sophomore album Re,…
items.content_html:
Originally written in 2017

“La Ingrata” is a track off of Mexican rock band Café Tacuba’s 1994 sophomore album Re, and the song lyrically culminates in a feminicide. Translated in English as “The Ungrateful Woman,” the song ends with a man informing his female lover, whom he just shot to death, that he will be in mourning at her funeral. La Santa Cecilia along with the Chilean singer-songwriter Mon Laferte recently covered the song for the Mexican-American band’s visual album Amar y Vivir, which was recorded live across Mexico City over the span of five days. A selection of mostly well-known Mexican songs like “El Último Trago,” “Leña de Pirul,” and the eponymous “Amar y Vivir,” the album is an ode to Mexico specifically and Latin America generally. The presence of “La Ingrata” in La Santa Cecilia’s album confirms the song’s status as a standard of Mexican music; and as a standard, the cover establishes the normalization of misogyny throughout Mexico.

A year before Re was released, journalists began reporting on the murders of women and girls along the Mexico/US border, especially in Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua. Since then, it has become evident that feminicides are a pervasive feature of Mexican life. According to a joint report released in 2016 by the Government of Mexico and the United Nations, there were approximately 47,178 feminicide victims in Mexico in a thirtyyear period (1985–2014).

Presently in Mexico, from Chihuahua to Chiapas, the feminicide rate is alarmingly high. Estado de México, the state that surrounds the majority of Mexico City, has been deemed “the most dangerous place to be female” given that between 2011 and 2012 1,258 women and girls were reported missing and 448 dead. The situation is so dire that municipalities across the country regularly issue what are called “gender alerts”—emergency declarations that are suppose to provide communities and law enforcement agencies with governmental resources with the aim of combatting feminicides. The ubiquitousness of feminicides led the Supreme Court of Mexico to rule in 2015 that any murder involving a woman or girl must be investigated as a possible feminicide.

Like feminicides, “La Ingrata” is pervasive and popular in Mexico since the 1990s. “La Ingrata” is as much characteristic of the contemporary Mexican songbook as telling of the standardization of violence faced by women, girls, and any feminine-read person. In Mexico as elsewhere, homophobia and transphobia are, after all, other forms misogyny takes—something Café Tacuba is well aware of. In fact in an interview with Argentine newspaper La Nación in late 2016, the Mexican rockers announced that they were considering whether to change the song’s lyrics or refrain from performing it altogether. Rubén Albarran, the lead singer of Café Tacuba, stated in the interview that it is precisely because a song is the manifestation of culture—inclusive of its practices and beliefs towards femininity—that he did not want to continue being an apologist for feminicides.

Performed as a ska punk parody of Mexico’s norteño music style, Café Tacuba’s version of “La Ingrata” is a spoof—affection in the guise of scorn or contempt masked as adoration, hard to tell. Regardless, there is a sense of resentment undergirding this ambiguity, which Rubén’s raspy and petulant voice relays to the female addressee of the song.

La Santa Cecilia and Mon Laferte’s cover, on the other hand, has lost the cranky tenor. Instead, the singers voices are full of sorrow conveying more sadness than anger. Amplifying this anguish is the ranchera’s arrangement, which incorporates bolero and danzón—music genres known for inducing nostalgia and widely understood to be representative of traditional Mexican music. This most recent iteration of the song is then in some ways about the loss of a social sense of loss. In other words, the nostalgia projected and produced by the singers approximates a longing for a longing for those lives who have been lost to gender-based violence.

Shot on a roof of a building next to Mexico City’s Zócalo (main square), arguably the symbolic heart of the country, the music video is ostensibly a musical performance of what currently ails the Mexican social body. In La Santa Cecilia’s cover of “La Ingrata,” the singers’ smoky yet firm voices can be heard as sonic apparitions of feminicide victims. The bitter sadness of the song induces lament not only for those who have been silenced through feminicide but also for a society’s silence on misogyny.

items.title: Las Meninas, Trapped
items.summary: Originally written in 2018 Mami, ¿yo soy guapa? Mami, ¿yo soy guapa? “The centre of the group is occupied by…
items.content_html:
Originally written in 2018

Mami, ¿yo soy guapa?
Mami, ¿yo soy guapa?

“The centre of the group is occupied by the little Infanta, with her flared pink and gray dress” (Foucault, 13)

Mi pelo rubio
Mi cara guapa

“she is a princess, but at the same time a little girl; she is most marvelously self-possessed in bearing, but is herself possessed by the court and by the royal lineage” (Alpers, 39)

Meninas feas
Mi cara guapa

“Like a donor in prayer, like an angel greeting the Virgin, a maid of honour on her knees is stretching out her hands towards the princess….A little to the right, there stands another maid of honour, also turned towards the Infanta, leaning slightly over her” (F, 13)

Quiero salir en un cuadro de Velazquez
Mami, ¿por qué no me pinta a mi Velazquez?
¿Por qué siempre salís tú y el papa?

“the royal couple, who are the spectacle itself” (F, 16)

Señorita Margarita, yo solo cumplo órdenes
Pero escuche un secreto yo la estoy pintando a usted

“how could we fail to see that invisibility, there in front of our eyes, since it has its own perceptible equivalent, its sealed-in figure, in the painting itself?” (F, 4)

¿Viste que en el cuadro se está pintando un cuadro?
¡Pues en realidad señora yo la estoy pintando A USTED!

“A mere confrontation, eyes catching one another’s glance, direct looks superimposing themselves upon one another as they cross. And yet this slender line of reciprocal visibility embraces a whole complex network of uncertainties, exchanges, and feints” (F, 5).

¿¡¡¡CÓMOOOO!!!?

“the spectator and the model, reverse their roles infinity” (F, 5)

ESTOY HACIENDO ALGO REVOLUCIONARIO
LLAMAME VELAZQUEZ AKA EXTRAORDINARIO
EL NIÑO DE SEVILLA VINO A SUBIR EL NIVEL
A ENSEÑARLE AL TONTO CÓMO SE TIENE QUE HACER

“Velázquez sees himself as part of the very court he sees through” (A, 40)

¿Entonces yo soy guapa?

“The entire picture is looking out at a scene for which it is itself a scene” (F, 15)

Mm.. sí

“That territory of the 'unsaid,' the impossible to say, to verbalize, is the privileged place that Las Meninas so amazingly exemplifies under the appearance of a simple, everyday, informal, 'frozen' family portrait” (de Diego, 167)

Es que no dejas hablar, no dejas hablar
A ver, es nuestro trabajo, es nuestro trabajo
Margarita, déjame hablar

“the world seen is before us because we… are what commanded its presence” (A, 38)

Margarita, escucha, un momento, por favor

“A shock that is augmented and made more inevitable still by a marginal trap” (F, 6)


Works Cited
Alpers, Svetlana. 1983. "Interpretation without Representation, or, the Viewing of Las Meninas." Representations 1: 30-42.

de Diego, Estrella. 2003. “Representing Representation: Reading Las Meninas, Again.” In Veláquez’s Las Meninas, edited by Suzanne L. Stratton-Pruitt, 150-169. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

Foucault, Michel. [1966] 2002. The Order of Things: An Archeology of the Human Sciences. London: Routledge.

items.title: Cien Años
items.summary: Cien años, 2020 The shared alienation of enclosed life during 2020 was reminiscent of the predicament at the center of…
items.content_html:
Cien años, 2020

The shared alienation of enclosed life during 2020 was reminiscent of the predicament at the center of Café Tacvba's 1994 story-song "El Metro." 

The song's narrator describes being stuck in the Mexico City subway system for months, amassing street wares from vendors and longing for their partner. The narrator's hair and wrinkles are growing, they're losing their sense of time, and all they want is a kiss from their partner who they fear has already forgotten about them. "El Metro" includes a short, bouncy melody on keyboard that repeats throughout and alludes to the Super Mario Bros. theme music. Café Tacvba reminds us of the familiar video game tune to express how riding the Mexico City subway system can feel at times like being on a lonely and whirlwind adventure in an underworld.

This poster / collage came about in the summer of 2020 when in the early months of the pandemic many of us agreed to take the challenge of what felt like 100 years of solitude. But then it was decided that those individuals acts of collective caregiving were too much. The effort to avoid peril was abandoned. Game over!

items.title: Sometimes It Snows In April
items.summary: Sometimes It Snows in April, 2016 March and April are peak jacaranda season in Mexico City. Back in April 2016…
items.content_html:
Sometimes It Snows in April, 2016

March and April are peak jacaranda season in Mexico City. Back in April 2016 while living in Toronto, I was working on this funky rendering of my former neighborhood when I learned Prince had passed. The jacaranda tree could no longer be depicted intact. Those cascading petals mark the end of a lush purple-tinged life. The 421 is the record of sunset as street address. He was right: Sometimes it snows in April.
